text: The 2025 Nowgam explosion was a major accidental blast that occurred on 14 November 2025 inside the Nowgam Police Station on the outskirts of Srinagar, in the Indian union territory of Jammu and Kashmir. The explosion happened while forensic and police teams were examining more than 300 kg of unstable explosive materials seized during an investigation into a suspected "white-collar" terror module. The blast killed nine people and injured between 27 and 32 others.
Indian authorities ruled out any militant involvement and called the incident an accidental detonation.

In early November 2025, security agencies in Haryana uncovered a suspected "white-collar" terror module and seized around 360 kg of explosive precursor materials, including ammonium nitrate, potassium nitrate, and sulphur. These materials were subsequently transferred to Nowgam Police Station for forensic analysis.
A joint team of forensic specialists, police personnel, and revenue officials assembled at the station on 14 November 2025 to examine the seized chemicals.
At approximately 23:20 IST, a powerful explosion ripped through the police station complex. CCTV footage showed a large fireball and shockwave that destroyed vehicles and damaged nearby buildings.
The blast triggered multiple smaller secondary explosions. Debris and human remains were found over 100 metres from the site.
Between 27 and 32 others were injured, including police personnel, forensic specialists, revenue officials, and civilians nearby.

Jammu & Kashmir DGP Nalin Prabhat described the incident as an accidental explosion caused by the instability of the seized material. No evidence of foul play or militant involvement was found in the initial investigation.
Forensic teams were deployed to determine the precise cause of the detonation.
The Jammu & Kashmir government announced compensation of ₹10 lakh for the families of the deceased and ₹1 lakh for those injured.
Security was tightened in the area, and a specialised investigation team was appointed to assess structural damage and review safety protocols.

Local leaders and civil society groups expressed grief and concern over the storage of large quantities of explosive materials within a police station located in a residential area. The incident reignited debate over safety procedures for handling seized explosives.

On 10 November 2025, a car exploded near the Red Fort in Delhi, India, killing at least 13 people and injuring more than twenty others. According to early police assessments, ammonium nitrate fuel oil and other explosives were used in the vehicle, which triggered the blast that damaged multiple nearby vehicles. The National Investigation Agency took over the case on the day of the incident. On 12 November, the Government of India formally declared the incident a terrorist attack. Subsequent forensic analysis identified the suspected bomber as Dr. Umar Mohammad (Umar Un Nabi), a doctor associated with a private medical college in Faridabad, after his DNA matched samples recovered from the wreckage. Investigators have also uncovered evidence suggesting the involvement of a white-collar terror module that included multiple doctors and other educated professionals.

On 9 November 2025, the Jammu and Kashmir Police, along with the Haryana Police, recovered around 350 kg of explosives, weapons, timing devices, and ammunition from a house in Faridabad. The following day, a second raid in the same city resulted in the recovery of approximately 2,563 kg of explosives, as well as chemicals, reagents, inflammable materials and electronic circuits used for manufacturing bombs; both houses had been rented by Mujammil Shakeel, a doctor from Pulwama in Jammu and Kashmir.

Police later arrested two other doctors from Jammu and Kashmir, Muzammil Ahmad Ganai of Pulwama and Adeel Majeed Rather of Qazigund, who were alleged to have links to Jaish-e-Mohammed and Ansar Ghazwat-ul-Hind. Subsequent media reports indicated that the doctor renting the Faridabad properties and the Red Fort blast suspect, Dr. Umar Mohammad (Umar Nabi Bhat), worked at the same private hospital in Faridabad. Police, however, have not officially confirmed any link between the Faridabad explosives seizures and the Red Fort car explosion.

At 6:52 pm IST on 10 November 2025, a car exploded near the Red Fort in Delhi. The car, which was identified as a white Hyundai i20, was parked near the Red Fort for more than three hours prior to the incident. CCTV footage showed the car entering a parking area adjacent to the Sunehri Mosque at 3:19 pm and remaining there until 6:48 pm. As per Satish Golcha, the Commissioner of Delhi Police, after leaving the parking, the car stopped at a traffic light near Gate 1 of the Red Fort Metro Station before moving and exploding in slow-moving traffic. He also said that there were two to three occupants inside the car at the time of the explosion, with CCTV footage indicating a masked man driving the car before the explosion. The investigation identified a core group of suspects, many holding professional roles. Dr. Umar Nabi, a Pulwama doctor, was confirmed by DNA to have driven the exploding car and was linked to a "white-collar" terror group. Another doctor, Dr. Muzammil Ganaie, was arrested after explosives were found in rooms rented under his name. Dr. Adeel Rather was arrested, with reports suggesting ties to Jaish-e-Mohammed, alongside Dr. Shaheen Saeed, who had weapons found in her vehicle.

Two muslim clerics, Maulvi Irfan Ahmad and Hafeez Ishtiyaq, were implicated in coordinating radicalization and the terror ecosystem. Finally, Tariq Ahmad Malik, Aamir Rashid, and his brother Umar Rashid were all arrested for their involvement in the logistical chain that transferred the explosive car to Dr. Umar.

After the Delhi Red Fort car explosion, security across the National Capital Region was significantly tightened. Noida and Ghaziabad police intensified vehicle checks, patrols, and surveillance at crowded locations such as metro stations and bus stands.

The Government of India officially declared the blast a terrorist incident, passing a resolution condemning the attack and urging agencies to identify the conspirators and their supporters. Prime Minister Narendra Modi also condemned the attack, saying the perpetrators "will not be spared."

Investigators uncovered what they described as a "deeper conspiracy" behind the blast, with a new FIR revealing criminal conspiracy elements. Police say the accused used "spycraft" techniques such as encrypted messages, silent draft emails, and possibly a private server to coordinate their activities.

According to the investigation, the suspected bomber, Dr. Umar Un Nabi, acted under panic after Faridabad raids that recovered large quantities of explosives, weapons, and detonators. Officials believe the bomb may have detonated prematurely because it was not fully developed or was mishandled.

Media reports further indicate that Umar was part of a larger "white-collar" terror network consisting of several doctors from Faridabad and Kashmir, with links to foreign handlers. Diaries and notebooks recovered during the investigation reportedly contain 25–30 names and coded entries detailing long-term planning.
The Delhi government announced compensation of ₹10 lakh for families of those killed in the blast and additional support for the injured.

The Press Information Bureau (PIB) fact-checked and debunked a widely shared image that showed a large fireball and a mushroom cloud, clarifying that this image was not from the Delhi blast but actually came from an Israeli airstrike in Beirut on 27 September 2024. PIB also rejected claims that the blast was caused by a CNG cylinder explosion, stating that no official from Delhi Police has made any such statement, and warned people not to share that fake narrative.

Additionally, some social media posts claimed that the blast was a false flag operation, but PIB strongly refuted these, labeling such claims as "fake and baseless" and warning that propaganda accounts are deliberately spreading confusion.

After the explosion, the area around the Red Fort was cordoned off, and teams from the National Security Guard (NSG) and forensic experts were deployed to collect evidence from the site. The Ministry of Home Affairs transferred the investigation to the National Investigation Agency (NIA) on the same day.

The Delhi Police registered a case under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act (UAPA) and the Explosives Act, citing suspected use of ammonium nitrate fuel oil (ANFO) and detonators recovered during the probe.

Investigators later traced the car used in the explosion to Dr. Umar Mohammad (Umar Nabi), a doctor from Pulwama who worked at Al-Falah University in Faridabad. Police sources told the media that Umar had alleged links to individuals arrested in Faridabad during earlier raids involving large quantities of explosives.
DNA analysis conducted by forensic laboratories confirmed that the human remains found in the vehicle matched those of Umar Mohammad, identifying him as the driver and suspected bomber.

On 14 November, Indian Army officials demolished Umar’s house in Quil village, Pulwama, under the Union Territory’s anti terror policy aimed at disrupting militant support networks. The family was evacuated beforehand. The Delhi Police later filed a fresh FIR outlining what they described as a "deeper conspiracy," alleging that a "doctor module" used encrypted apps, operational secrecy, and structured planning to execute the attack.

Home Minister Amit Shah directed agencies to track down all culprits, saying "all involved will face the full wrath of our agencies". Prime Minister Narendra Modi condemned the attack, expressed grief, and promised justice.
According to a Times of India report, President Droupadi Murmu was briefed by Amit Shah; she was concerned and followed up.

The U.S. State Department expressed condolences and said it was closely monitoring the situation. The Chinese Foreign Ministry expressed "deep sorrow" and was "shocked" by the blast. French ambassador Thierry Mathou extended condolences on behalf of France. Japan's ambassador Ono Keiichi expressed deep sadness and prayers for the injured. Maldives president Mohamed Muizzu said he was "deeply saddened" and expressed solidarity with India. Iran's Minister of Foreign Affairs expressed its "deep sorrow" and extended sympathies to India. Israel's foreign minister, Gideon Sa'ar, extended his condolences and expressed solidarity. Nepal's interim prime minister Sushila Karki expressed deepest condolences and solidarity with India. Ireland's Tánaiste, Simon Harris, expressed support and sorrow for the victims. The Argentine ambassador to India expressed condolences and wished speedy recovery to the injured. The United Kingdom high commissioner to India, Lindy Cameron, expressed her sorrow; the UK also issued a travel advisory.
